header_summary:
A novel One-Shot Replace-By-Fee-Rate (OSRBF) mechanism for the Bitcoin network has been proposed to address the shortcomings of the current Replace-by-Fee policy by emphasizing fee-rates. This method seeks to alleviate transaction pinning and improve the efficiency and security of second-layer protocols, with support from Fulgur Ventures. Additionally, an innovative solution named BitBlend has been introduced to preemptively tackle the impending 2106 timestamp overflow problem in Bitcoin's 32-bit block timestamp field, offering a backward-compatible method without requiring a hard fork, as detailed in the available white paper at [https://bitblend2106.github.io/bitcoin/BitBlend2106.pdf](https://bitblend2106.github.io/bitcoin/BitBlend2106.pdf).

On the technical front, developers are urged to judiciously incorporate x-only public keys in multisignature protocols, balancing efficiency gains with potential security risks. In parallel, the community reflects on Bitcoin's protocol evolution, stressing the importance of user consensus and minority soft forks in the face of opposition from entities with regulatory or custodial motives. The community also acknowledges that Bitcoin's value is grounded in its scarcity and transparent supply, suggesting that accommodating large block processing in the future could enhance the cryptocurrency's utility and worth.

Contributions to the Bitcoin codebase continue to advance, with new pull requests focusing on CSFS and INTERNALKEY features submitted to the 'binana' repository, available for review and collaboration at [https://github.com/bitcoin-inquisition/binana/pull/1](https://github.com/bitcoin-inquisition/binana/pull/1), [https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29269](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29269), and [https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29270](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29270). There is ongoing discussion about applying a similar approach to the CTV proposal, considering the division into two separate PRs to streamline the integration and testing processes.

recent_posts.title: One-Shot Replace-By-Fee-Rate
recent_posts.summary:
- A new Bitcoin transaction replacement method focuses on fee-rate rather than total fee.
- The One-Shot Replace-By-Fee-Rate policy aims to prevent transaction pinning and prioritize miner revenue.
- Fee-rate-based replacement has resistance to bandwidth attacks, bolstering network efficiency and security.

recent_posts.title: BitBlend Proposal for 2106
recent_posts.summary:
- BitBlend2106 proposes using the last 32 bits of timestamps to avoid Bitcoin's 2106 overflow issue.
- The approach ensures compatibility and a seamless overflow correction process within Bitcoin's system.
- Feedback on BitBlend's white paper is invited via Proton Mail for collaborative refinement.

recent_posts.title: MuSig2 derivation, descriptor, and PSBT field BIPs
recent_posts.summary:
- X-only public keys enhance efficiency but introduce cryptographic challenges.
- Key aggregation in multisignature schemes requires careful handling for security.
- Optimizing key representation demands a thorough understanding to prevent system flaws.

recent_posts.title: On consensus changes in bitcoin 2024
recent_posts.summary:
- The email addresses Bitcoin protocol changes and the history of the block size conflict.
- It discusses the evolution of threats and Bitcoin's need for adaptive governance mechanisms.
- The author supports consensus via signaling and defends participant autonomy in soft forks.

recent_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's value is based on scarcity, transparency, and permissionless transactions.
- Technological advancements in block size and mining could enhance Bitcoin's utility.
- Improvements should retain Bitcoin's fundamental qualities to increase its value.

recent_posts.title: LNHANCE bips and implementation

active_posts.title: Compressed Bitcoin Transactions
active_posts.summary:
- Tom Briar developed a bitcoin transaction compression schema for low-bandwidth channels.
- The schema ensures common single-party transactions remain uncorrupted when compressed.
- Tom submitted a pull request for his compression schema implementation.

active_posts.title: [BUG]: Bitcoin blockspace price discrimination put simple transactions at disadvantage
active_posts.summary:
- Pricing discrepancies in blockspace favor complex over simple transactions.
- The current model discourages simple transactions and may lead to centralization.
- A uniform pricing strategy and Segwit update are proposed for fairness and efficiency.

active_posts.title: BIP process friction
active_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin Improvement Proposals repository has issues with merging delays and narrowing scope.
- Luke is the sole BIP editor responsible for assigning new numbers, causing bottlenecks.
- Aj introduces BINANA, a separate system for numbering bitcoin-related proposals, to bypass BIP inefficiencies.

active_posts.title: 64 bit arithmetic soft fork
active_posts.summary:
- A review calls for 64-bit arithmetic to enhance TLUV and other protocols.
- A Bitcoin Improvement Proposal is public for comments at the provided link.
- Early feedback is sought for the proposal and its accompanying implementation.

active_posts.title: Unspendable keys in descriptors
active_posts.summary:
- Taproot and miniscript integration in Bitcoin Core offers new wallet development potentials.
- Generating indistinguishable and unique unspendable keys for hardware signers poses challenges.
- Various methods for creating unspendable keys exist, each with distinct advantages and compromises.

active_posts.title: Lightning transactions with v3 and ephemeral anchors
active_posts.summary:
- Proposed changes focus on v3 transactions and ephemeral anchors to optimize lightning deals.
- New system aims to remove on-chain fee dependency and simplify commitment transactions.
- Transition involves non-disruptive upgrade paths, with a consideration of node operators' preferences.

today_in_history_posts.title: Purge attacks (spin on sabotage attacks)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The Purge attack involves replacing blocks with empty ones to disrupt Bitcoin transactions.
- Attackers entice users to double-spend, challenging transaction consensus and trust in Bitcoin.
- The report detailing defense against sabotage like Purge attacks seeks user feedback.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Passive investment acquires assets with no active management, while active involves direct engagement.
- Passive investing issues include the principal/agent problem and the potential for underutilized assets.
- The blog suggests central banks might stabilize economies using inflationary currency backed by Bitcoin.
